metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary**

**C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021: Raj Kumar Sharma vs Sandeep Kumar & Anr.**

**Background**

This case involves a dispute over the use of a trade mark "PIZZA GALLERIA" by two separate parties in different locations in India. The petitioner, Raj Kumar Sharma, owns eateries under the name "PIZZA GALLERIA" in Rewari, while the respondent, Sandeep Kumar, also operates under the same name but outside of Rewari.

**Legal Issues**

1. **Trade Mark Registration**: The case revolves around the registration of the trade mark "PIZZA GALLERIA" by Sandeep Kumar (Respondent 1) under Class 30 of the Alphabetical Index of classification of goods published by the Registrar of Trade Marks.
2. **Rectification of Register**: Raj Kumar Sharma has filed a petition under Section 571 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, seeking to rectify the register by removing the trade mark registration in favor of Respondent 1.
3. **Geographical Restraint**: The dispute centers on whether Respondent 1 is entitled to use the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark in Rewari, given that petitioner has already established an existing business under the same name.

**Arguments**

* Raj Kumar Sharma's advocate (Nikhil Sonker): Argued that respondent is seeking to trade off the goodwill of petitioner's business, which cannot be allowed.
* Sandeep Kumar's advocate (Garima Sachdeva): Emphasized that respondent intends to use the mark outside Rewari and is not willing to restrict their use exclusively to those areas.

**Court Findings**

The Court was unable to understand why it should intervene in this dispute, as petitioner has no objection to Respondent 1 using the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark outside of Rewari. However, due to Respondent 1's insistence on not restricting their use, the court proceeded with the case.

**Decision**

The Court denied Raj Kumar Sharma's petition under Section 571 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, which sought the rectification of the register by removing the registration number "4842932" dated July 5th, 2021. The decision was influenced largely because petitioner had expressed no objection to Respondent 1 using the mark outside Rewari.

**Consequence**

Although petitioner's objections were not allowed in this context, this outcome may indicate that they can use this as leverage for future disputes or negotiations regarding trade mark rights within their operational areas (Rewari).

Please note that court decisions are binding; however interpretation requires understanding of legal reasoning behind each decision.

the MoU dated 9th June 2020.  However, in para 13 of the grounds of 
challenge in the present petition, the petitioner has stated that the 
petitioner‟s earlier application was for a mark similar to the impugned 
mark of Respondent 1 and that, therefore, grant of registration to the 
impugned mark infracted Section 11(1) of the Trademarks Act.  As 
such, it cannot be said that the submission of Mr. Sonker is entirely 
divorced from the pleadings.   
 
23. 
Section 57(2) of the Trademarks Act permits the making of an 
application for making, expunging or varying any entry in the Trade 
Marks Register, where the applicant alleges that (i) the entry is made 
without sufficient cause or (ii) is wrongly remaining on the register or 
(iii) suffers from any error or defect.  Mr. Sonker submits that 
circumstance (ii) applies to the present case.  As such, he submits, in 
view of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, the impugned 
registration of the word mark “PIZZA GALLERIA” granted to the 
petitioner on 5th July 2021, could not be allowed to remain on the

5th July 2021 is violative of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trademarks Act, 
the said word mark is liable to be removed from the register.  
However, as Mr Sonker has restricted his challenge, in the present 
petition, to the use, by the defendant, of the impugned “PIZZA 
GALLERIA” mark in the city of Rewari, I direct the rectification of 
Registration No. 4842932 granted to Respondent 1 for the word mark 
“PIZZA GALLERIA” on 5th July 2021 to be rectified by inserting, 
therein, a disclaimer disallowing the use of the said mark, by the 
defendant, in the city of Rewari, while retaining the right of the 
defendant to use the mark elsewhere in the country.   
 
25. 
This petition stands disposed of in the aforesaid terms.  
 
A Postscript 
 
26. 
A somewhat quixotic statutory position has come to my notice 
while correcting this judgement.  Earlier, classification of goods and 
services, for the purposes of registration of trade marks, was contained 
in the Fourth Schedule to the Trade Marks Rules, 2002 (“the 2002 TM 
Rules”).  The 2002 TM Rules were, subsequently, superseded by the 
Trade Marks Rules, 2017 (“the 2017 TM Rules”).  Rule 185 of the 
2017 TM Rules repeals the 2002 Rules “without prejudice to anything 
done under such rules before the coming into force of” the 2017 TM 
Rules.  New Registrations have, therefore, to be as per the 2017 TM 
Rules, and cannot abide by the 2002 TM Rules.  I am informed, 
however, that, even as on date, a registrant seeking to register a trade 
mark has to classify the mark as per the 2002 TM Rules.  This appears 
to be erroneous, in view of Rule 185 of the 2017 TM Rules supra.   
 
Digitally Signed
By:KAMLA RAWAT
Signing Date:31.01.2023
12:51:34
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 11 ---
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000647 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021

27. 
That apart, Section 7(1) of the Trade Marks Act requires the 
Registrar of Trade Marks to classify goods and services, as far as may 
be, in accordance with the International classification of goods and 
services (the NICE Classification) for the purposes of registration of 
trade marks.  Section 7(2) makes the decision of any question as to the 
class within which any goods or services falls, by the Registrar, final.  
Section 8(1) requires the Registrar to publish, in the prescribed 
manner, an alphabetical list of classification of goods and services for 
the purpose of registration of trade marks.  These provisions, 
therefore, require the Registrar to classify the goods or services, for 
the purpose of registration, in accordance with the NICE 
classification, only as far as may be.  Rule 20(1) of the 2017 TM 
Rules, however, departs, somewhat, from Section 7(1) of the TM Act, 
as it makes classification of goods and services, for the purpose of 
registration of trade marks, to be mandatorily “as per current edition 
of „the international Classification of goods and services (NICE 
classification)‟ published by the WIPO.  Thus, where Section 7(1) 
makes the NICE classification applicable for classification of goods 
and services under the TM Act only as far as may be, Rule 20(1) 
makes it mandatory for the classification of goods and services to 
abide by the NICE classification.  There is, therefore, an apparent 
discrepancy between Section 7(1) of the TM Act and Rule 20(1) of the 
TM Rules.  This may need statutory correction. 
 
28. 
The Registrar of Trade Marks is requested to examine this 
aspect.

tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary: Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr.**

Source: https://www.hcportal.delhi.nic.in/PDF%20Court/DHC/2023/2023DHC000647.pdf (Page 1-8 of 11)

**Date:** Not specified, but cited as "2023/DHC/000647" and a signing date of January 31, 2023.

**Parties:**

* Raj Kumar Sharma (Petitioner)
* Sandeep Kumar & Anr. (Respondents)

**Facts:**

* The petitioner seeks to register his device mark containing a pictorial depiction of a pizza with the word "Galleria" alongside.
* The respondent has previously registered their word mark "PIZZA GALLERIA".

**Legal Arguments:**

* The court considers whether the two marks are similar, which would result in a likelihood of confusion under Section 2(1)(h) of the Trade Marks Act.
* The petitioner's device mark and the respondent's word mark are considered to be similar, as an average consumer may connect them immediately.
* The court notes that the "Galleria" part of the marks is dominant, and an unwary consumer would likely regard the two establishments as one administration.

**Decisions:**

* The court finds in favor of the petitioner, holding that the respondent's word mark "PIZZA GALLERIA" is deceptively similar to the petitioner's device mark.
* The court cites Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act to support its decision, and reference cases Mex Switchgears Pvt. Ltd. v. Omex Cables Industries and Natures Essence Private Limited v. Protogreen Retail Solutions Private Limited.

**Conclusion:**

The court rules in favor of the petitioner, holding that the respondent's word mark is deceptively similar to their own device mark, and thus liable for infringement.

**Court Decision**: The court considers whether the device mark of the petitioner and the "PIZZA GALLERIA" word mark of the respondent are similar and could cause a likelihood of confusion among consumers.

**Key Points**:

* The expression "similar" is not defined in the Trade Marks Act, but Section 2(1)(h) deems a mark to be deceptively similar if it so nearly resembles another mark as to be likely to deceive or cause confusion.
* The petitioner's mark contains a pictorial depiction of a pizza with the word "Galleria" alongside, while the respondent's mark is "PIZZA GALLERIA", where "Galleria" is the dominant part.

**Relevance**: This case discusses trade mark similarity and likelihood of confusion, a key aspect of intellectual property law. (PDF source: 40. Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf)

13. 
Can, then, the 
 device mark of the petitioner, and the

14. 
After some cogitation, I feel the answer has to be in the

15. 
The expression “similar” is not defined in the Trade Marks Act.  
Section 2(1)(h), however, declares, in an admirably circular fashion, 
that “a mark shall be deemed to be deceptively similar to another mark 
if it so nearly resembles the other mark as to be likely to deceive or 
cause confusion”.   Thus, Section 2(1)(h) embraces, within the broad 
parentheses of “deceptive similarity”, both “confusing” and 
“deceptive” similarity.  Likelihood of deception or confusion, in any 
event, remains the pervading mantra.

**Court Decision Summary**

Document Source: 40. Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf (High Court of Delhi)

**Case Details**

* Case No.: C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021
* Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000647
* Date: January 30, 2023

**Parties**

* Plaintiff: Raj Kumar Sharma (represented by Mr. Nikhil Sonker)
* Defendants: Sandeep Kumar & Anr. (represented by Ms. Garima Sachdeva and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar)

**Facts and Decisions**

* The plaintiff challenged the registration of the word mark "PIZZA GALLERIA" (Registration No. 4842932) on behalf of the defendant.
* The Court held that the use of the impugned mark in Rewari city is violative of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trademarks Act, and the registration should be rectified with a disclaimer disallowing its use in Rewari while retaining the right to use elsewhere in India.

**Arguments and Decisions**

* Mr. Sonker argued that the registration was invalid due to non-compliance with Section 11(1)(b).
* The Court decided in favor of the plaintiff, ordering the rectification of the mark as requested.

**Notes on Statutory Position**

* A discrepancy has been noted regarding the classification of goods and services for trademark registration between Sections 7 and 8 of the Trade Marks Act and Rule 20 of the 2017 TM Rules.
* The Registrar of Trade Marks is requested to examine this aspect for statutory correction.

5th July 2021 is violative of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trademarks Act,

However, as Mr Sonker has restricted his challenge, in the present 
petition, to the use, by the defendant, of the impugned “PIZZA 
GALLERIA” mark in the city of Rewari, I direct the rectification of 
Registration No. 4842932 granted to Respondent 1 for the word mark 
“PIZZA GALLERIA” on 5th July 2021 to be rectified by inserting,

defendant to use the mark elsewhere in the country.   
 
25. 
This petition stands disposed of in the aforesaid terms.  
 
A Postscript 
 
26. 
A somewhat quixotic statutory position has come to my notice 
while correcting this judgement.  Earlier, classification of goods and 
services, for the purposes of registration of trade marks, was contained 
in the Fourth Schedule to the Trade Marks Rules, 2002 (“the 2002 TM 
Rules”).  The 2002 TM Rules were, subsequently, superseded by the 
Trade Marks Rules, 2017 (“the 2017 TM Rules”).  Rule 185 of the 
2017 TM Rules repeals the 2002 Rules “without prejudice to anything 
done under such rules before the coming into force of” the 2017 TM 
Rules.  New Registrations have, therefore, to be as per the 2017 TM 
Rules, and cannot abide by the 2002 TM Rules.  I am informed, 
however, that, even as on date, a registrant seeking to register a trade 
mark has to classify the mark as per the 2002 TM Rules.  This appears 
to be erroneous, in view of Rule 185 of the 2017 TM Rules supra.

Here is a summary of Page 11 from the provided PDF:

**Neutral Citation Number:** 2023/DHC/000647
**Case Name:** Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr.

On January 30, 2023, in a judgment delivered by C. Hari Shankar J, it was observed that there is an apparent discrepancy between Section 7(1) of the Trade Marks Act and Rule 20(1) of the TM Rules regarding classification of goods and services. According to Section 7(1), the Registrar of Trade Marks classifies goods and services "as far as may be" in accordance with the International Classification (NICE Classification), whereas Rule 20(1) makes it mandatory to follow the NICE classification.

The court requested the Registrar of Trade Marks to examine this aspect and suggested a need for statutory correction. 

**Source:** 40. Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf
nodes.content:
Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000647 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021 
                                                        Page 11 of 11  
 
   
 
27. 
That apart, Section 7(1) of the Trade Marks Act requires the 
Registrar of Trade Marks to classify goods and services, as far as may 
be, in accordance with the International classification of goods and 
services (the NICE Classification) for the purposes of registration of 
trade marks.  Section 7(2) makes the decision of any question as to the 
class within which any goods or services falls, by the Registrar, final.  
Section 8(1) requires the Registrar to publish, in the prescribed 
manner, an alphabetical list of classification of goods and services for 
the purpose of registration of trade marks.  These provisions, 
therefore, require the Registrar to classify the goods or services, for 
the purpose of registration, in accordance with the NICE 
classification, only as far as may be.  Rule 20(1) of the 2017 TM 
Rules, however, departs, somewhat, from Section 7(1) of the TM Act, 
as it makes classification of goods and services, for the purpose of 
registration of trade marks, to be mandatorily “as per current edition 
of „the international Classification of goods and services (NICE 
classification)‟ published by the WIPO.  Thus, where Section 7(1) 
makes the NICE classification applicable for classification of goods 
and services under the TM Act only as far as may be, Rule 20(1) 
makes it mandatory for the classification of goods and services to 
abide by the NICE classification.  There is, therefore, an apparent 
discrepancy between Section 7(1) of the TM Act and Rule 20(1) of the 
TM Rules.  This may need statutory correction. 
 
28. 
The Registrar of Trade Marks is requested to examine this 
aspect. 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J
